Ultimately, biochemistry used for COVID-19 is not disease-specific. Lab work spans so much care:
‚Äì admission
‚Äì stratifying risk
‚Äì resource allocation
‚Äì specific COVID-19 treatments
‚Äì recovery
‚Äì secondary infections
‚Äì complications
‚Äì presence of sHLH /COVID CSS
   +++

Dr Ryan is now talking through COVID cytokine storm syndrome. A COVID-specific form of secondary haemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis: hypercytokinaemia, multiorgan failure, unremitting fever, cytopenias, hyperferritinaemia and pulmonary involvement, including ARDS.

Inflammation markers are very important and help to define:
‚Äì diagnosis severity
‚Äì prognosis
‚Äì presence of secondary infection
‚Äì possibly useful to guide specific treatments

What markers for #COVID19?
‚Äì C reactive protein 
‚Äì Ferritin
‚Äì Procalcitonin
‚Äì Interleukin-6

And now liver injury. The infection enters through ACE2 receptors. Factors contributing to liver damage include direct viral effect, drug-induced liver injury, pre-existing liver disease + more. These activate inflammatory cytokine storm, when pathogenic T cells are activated.

Dr Kathryn Ryan is discussing acute kidney injury. Risk factors include increased age, race, diabetes, hypertension, cardiovascular disease, mechanical ventilation and vasoactive medications.

34% patients with community-acquired pneumonia in hospital developed AKI.
Testing and monitoring is key for COVID-19, helping to make sure patients are cared for in the best place for them.

Tonight, our expert seminar is led by @kathryan @BelfastTrust and focuses on the vital role of the #biochemistry laboratory in #COVID19 management, which includes diagnosis, screening, monitoring and research.

https://t.co/7lIwP5RRu5

We found that talk incredibly insightful. We had a wide range of questions and very informative answers. If you missed it, it‚Äôll be on our website soon at https://t.co/7lIwP5RRu5.

Thank you to Dr Mike Osborn and Dr Brian Hanley, and our audience, for your time.

There have been quite a few questions about best practice and guidance. The College has a range of guidance and advice, including for care of the deceased and broader histopathology. All can be found at our COVID-19 resources hub: https://t.co/4yoR3o6Woa

What does severe COVID-19 look like? This study found similar findings to others around the world.

There were a variety of patterns that, although modulated, included immune cell depletion, diffuse alveolar damage, thrombosis and histiocyte activation.

Some overall findings for discussion now: DAD is the most consistent feature in lungs. All patients with full post-mortems had >=1 thrombus. Many cases had cardiomegaly, fibrointimal thickening and obesity. They found haemophagocytosis, and T-cell depletion.

Dr Osborn and Dr Hanley are exploring a range of very detailed findings now: lung, cardiovascular, haematopoietic, liver, renal, and more.

We couldn't possibly cover them all here, so make sure you watch back later!

Results: median time from onset of symptoms to death was 14 days; full range was 9.5‚Äì23.3 days.

Major comorbidities: hypertension, COPD, type II diabetes ‚Äì many of the expected ones.

All cases had elevated levels of all expected inflammatory markers and low lymphocyte counts.
Key was good PPE and limited biopsy post mortems with the help of clinical teams. Biopsies from organs gave better samples and, hopefully, better opportunity for molecular studies.

Findings were also needed to help research. Their findings come from consented hospital PMs to HTA standards. Nine full PMs and one limited PM.

Ethical approval, too, was sought from and given by Imperial College Healthcare Tissue bank.

In the UK, autopsy findings began to come through before the country had cases. The speakers' initiated their study into COVID19-positive cases because clinicians needed to learn from the deceased to help them care for the living.

As tonight's seminar closes, we‚Äôd like to thank Dr Catherine Moore (@SmallRedOne) for her insightful talk on the safety aspects of processing samples in labs. Thank you also to our audience for questions.

If you missed it, it‚Äôll be on our website soon: https://t.co/7lIwP5RRu5

Implications for routine labs? Viral RNA found in range of samples, but risk low unless aerosol-generating. Avoid open bench work for suspected cases. Cleaning: greatest risk from chemicals used to inactivate surfaces. Solutions must have proven activity on enveloped RNA viruses.
Special considerations are necessary for post-mortem samples. Fresh tissue is often received and strict regulations should be followed (e.g. samples destroyed during processing).

In a CL2 lab, meanwhile, the greatest risk comes from leaking samples and spills. As samples arrive double bagged, it can be hard to ascertain sample integrity.

Viral inactivation strategies should be used, for example, the addition of swab to lysis buffer, and heat inactivation

Containment level 3 (CL3) laboratories pose greater challenges than lower-level areas. Reduced workforce can cause bottlenecks in workflow (of 2,500‚Äì3,000 samples a day!), waste is increased and there is greater need for decontamination of external surfaces.
Lab workers have the knowledge and skills to deal with the risks arising from the nature of the agent and their environment, including reporting, training, protocols, equipment, etc.

Assessing risk is vital. Safety has two sections more closely related during a pandemic: routine diagnostics and research laboratory. Local risk assessments should consider the agent, host and environment to be able to mitigate effectively.
Dr Catherine Moore has begun by discussing the wider implications of laboratory accidents, which can include reduced public confidence, decreased funding and laboratory-acquired infections.

We‚Äôve just closed a fascinating seminar on a hot topic ‚Äì testing outside the NHS. We‚Äôd like to thank @RachaelLiebmann for an engaging talk and our viewers for interesting questions.

If you missed it, we'll put the recording online soon. Keep an eye on https://t.co/7lIwP5RRu5

Now running through community testing example of Brent and Harrow CCG. Service setup within a week of formal request and another CCG seeking the service. 

But, misunderstanding remains ‚Äì 'Why can't it be like IKEA?' Understanding of labs and services needs to be more widespread.

Questions may arise around UKAS accreditation ‚Äì do they meet ISO15189? No, but highly unlikely to achieve in such a short space of time. Is there integrated IT? In some cases. What is their role in serology? To ponder for the future.

QA layers for field labs: UK NEQAS, UKAS visits and visit check list: e.g. operational management, staffing, BCT, liability and indemnity, SOPs, trouble shooting, training, competencies, IQC, EQA, validation, transport, follow-up, sample and specimen reception, PPE and on and on

Global shortages make procurement a dog-eat-dog world. Related pressures also meant that testing restrictions were in place. New programmes needed to be developed: lighthouse labs and the Francis Crick Institute are two great examples.
Regulation and accreditation in the NHS is broad and thorough. It is mirrored, though, across the private sector ‚Äì CQC, GMC, HCPC, UKAS, NHSBT, SHOT and EQA. The regulatory burden is shared.

Private practice has been changing in recent years, so governance can be complicated ‚Äì there are self-employed pathologists and privately employed scientists in private practice and NHS employed-pathologists and privately employed scientists in the public‚Äìprivate joint ventures.

To begin with, Dr Rachael Liebmann is discussing some of the public relations difficulties facing the initial testing programmes ‚Äì including delays and errors ‚Äì and how these are all happening right in front of a very engaged public.

This week‚Äôs #COVID19 seminar is presented by our Vice President of Communications and International, and Group Medical Director of The Doctors Laboratory and Health Services Laboratories, @RachaelLiebmann. We‚Äôll be exploring regulatory and QA issues of testing outside the NHS.

Thank you so much to @UCLInfectImm‚Äôs Prof Judith Breuer, who has given us a wonderful overview of next-gen sequencing and how it‚Äôs being used to understand, treat and intervene #COVID19.

If you missed us this week, we‚Äôll be sharing the recording soon: https://t.co/7lIwP5RRu5
#COVID19 is here to stay ‚Äì certainly through our lifetimes. It is not yet possible to say what will happen, but sequencing will help us monitor the mutations and how well any vaccine works.

Interesting question on travel: should we now quarantine? We should always work fast ‚Äì e.g. Australia used testing, tracing and quarantining very quickly. We have the technology to work out *who* to quarantine ‚Äì subject to using a modern approach from the start.

And, importantly, no evidence the virus is from a lab of any kind ‚Äì the virus has emerged from a bat, via another animal,  into humans, due to our close and increasing connection with the animal world.

No evidence that lineage associated with clinical outcome or viral load differences. No resistance mutations yet described. Some mutations are occurring independently on different branches of phylogenic tree. No evidence associated with virulence/attenutation/adaptation to humans

COG UK is exploring hospital-onset COVID infection to identify whether rapid (<48 hours) sequencing better defines infections and whether it can be used to reduce outbreaks.

Using granular and possibly more simple way of tracing.

Genotypes in UK are wide-ranging ‚Äì more than 30. This provides data on the heterogeneity against which a vaccine needs to act.

Genomics also enables us to identify where hotspots of transmission are and provides local spread patterns.

New consortium, @CovidGenomicsUK, is deliver large-scale and rapid whole-genome virus sequencing ‚Äì 17,000 so far (most in the world). This will enhance transmission understanding, enable monitoring of interventions and treatment and expand biological knowledge and research.

Sequencing can identify transmissions, empowering contract tracing networks. With current data, it‚Äôs estimated that ~30% of transmissions occur within households, while 6‚Äì20% are in hospital and care home settings.

Sequencing identifies geographically segregated genotypes. The virus is now a range of genotypes

Phylogeography ‚Äì study of geographic distributions of those of particular genealogical lineage ‚Äì enables identification of first UK strain to spread. Appears to have been from Italy.

How does sequencing help understanding of the virus? It provides insights into the origins of SARS-CoV-2, showing how long it‚Äôs been around ‚Äì it diverged from known bat viruses as long as 40‚Äì70 years ago.

This week‚Äôs #COVID19 seminar looks at next-gen sequencing of the virus ‚Äì explained by Professor Judith Breuer, Professor of Virology @UCLInfectImm.

It‚Äôs just kicking off now with a look at the timeline of the outbreak, genome identification and rates of evolutionary mutation.

And that‚Äôs our fifth #COVID19 seminar over. A huge thank you to @SunetraGupta for her fascinating talk on #epidemiology and to our audience for their interesting questions.

If you missed the seminar, we‚Äôll be uploading it soon at: https://t.co/HYDdbjxLG4

Stratification of vulnerability plays an important role too.

Ultimately: As data accumulate, we will be able to narrow down the scenarios using a sliding scale to predict with greater accuracy what will happen in the future.

The proportion of those immune at a particular date is linked to the date of the pandemic's introduction. Determining the level of exposure is critical to using this relationship.

Infection prevalence can be identified through serological surveys and presence of antibodies.
Through modelling, epidemiologists can identify what is happening with a pandemic. To identify cumulative mortality through models, they use the infection fatality rate over time.

Professor Gupta exploring why we use mathematical modelling for understanding COVID19: all pathogens have different life history strategies and models stratify the population, so they can be used to connect the virus to a population's dynamics.

And we‚Äôre off. @SunetraGupta is explaining that epidemiology is about producing mechanistic hypotheses for how a disease is transmitting and so help to reveal what fundamental biological processes are involved.

Our fifth #COVID19 seminar will soon begin and we‚Äôre very excited.

And that‚Äôs a wrap. A huge thank you to Dr Kate Templeton and everyone who joined us. We covered a lot of ground, with a lot of interesting questions and answers at the end.

If you missed it tonight, we‚Äôll be uploading the recorded seminar soon at: https://t.co/HYDdbjxLG4
To summarise, we're a team in a tough match. Diagnostics are facing incredible challenges ‚Äì everything has been achieved through incredible teamwork. #Collaboration is key.

Very important: PCR only works around clinical algorithms. 

So negative COVID tests: is there value repeating them? Dr Kate Templeton says you get diminishing returns, though the first repeat test is often positive.
Testing pathways can be challenging, but multiple assays offer lots of options to labs. A huge amount of work has been undertaken across Scotland to achieve this.

The PCR test: incredible speed of development. The work began on 20 Jan with PHE Colindale, control dispatched on 5 Feb and live by 10 Feb. Testing ramped up quickly up to 1,000 a day within a week, peaking just under 4,000.

PCR testing has to happen within ten days of infection. But what's the right sample? In mild cases, the nose gives the greatest yield, followed by the throat. But in hospital cases, just 65% of nose swabs are +ve, while ETT hits 100%.

Our second expert-led #COVID19 seminar has kicked off ‚Äì this one‚Äôs on PCR diagnostics. Professor Will Irving has introduced Dr Kate Templeton, who is now talking about how to diagnose in the first seven days: it‚Äôs vital testing, results and reporting all happen at the right time.

@debrasusanmilne RCPath members will frequently put a comment on some results to point out that the result should be interpreted with caution, for example if the patient is on a certain medicine which interferes with a test.
@debrasusanmilne No test is 100% correct all of the time but we approach 99.9% with the majority of other pathology tests carried out in accredited laboratories.

@debrasusanmilne Or perhaps the particular test is not particularly sensitive. False positives can occur because of contamination and some stocks of primers circulated for COVID-19 testing were contaminated.

@debrasusanmilne We have always known about false positive and false negative COVID-19 tests. Sometimes false negatives can be because the test has been taken too early in the course of the disease - or too late when the virus is present deep in the lungs.
